column1: Bantayan is the main and largest island of the Bantayan island group that lies close to the geographical centre of the Philippine archipelago.
The island group includes numerous smaller islands (some uninhabited or uninhabitable)
column2: mostly around the southwest corner of the island. About 20 of these islets stretch for about 8 kilometres (5 miles) southwest from Bantayan municipality port area
column3: with some nearer ones being accessible on foot from the main island at low tide. The islands are beside the busy shipping lanes for ships and ferries coming from Mindanao or Cebu City on their way to Manila. The islands are all small and green and low
column4: virtually indistinguishable one from another.

column1: The Bantayanon language is mostly a mixture of different neighbouring Visayan languages: The principally native Cebuano (from Cebu and Eastern Negros) and Hiligaynon (from Western Negros and Iloilo)
column2: Boholano (from Bohol)
column3: Masbateño (from Masbate) and Waray-Waray (from Leyte and Samar).  However it has its own words such as "kakyop" (yesterday)
column4: "sara" (today) and "buwas" (tomorrow).

column1: The climate is typically equatorial – temperature range over the year is less than three degrees Celsius (5.4 deg F)
column2: and annual rainfall exceeds 1
column3: 500 millimetres (59 in).  January to April inclusive are less wet than the other months.  This supports at least two rice crops per year.  The climate in Bantayan falls within Coronas climate type IV
column4: characterised by not very pronounced maximum rainfall with a short dry season from one to three months and a wet season of nine to ten months. The dry season starts in February and lasts through April sometimes extending to mid‑May.

column1: Bantayan has a tropical climate. Most months of the year are marked by significant rainfall. The short dry season has little impact. This location is classified as Am (Tropical monsoon climate) by Köppen–Geiger climate classification system.

column1: Bantayan and its surrounding islands have been included in several pieces of legislation giving protected status.
In 1981 President Marcos signed proclamation no. 2151 giving certain parts of the country protected status.  This included Bantayan Island with the status of a "Wilderness Area"
column2: although its physical extent was undefined
column3: albeit the proclamation described all the areas named as "containing an aggregate area of 4
column4: 326 hectares
column5: more or less".  Eleven years later the Philippine Congress passed Republic Act 7586 – the National Integrated Protected Areas System (NIPAS) Act of 1992
column6: managed by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) – which reaffirmed the protected status.  However it too did not specify the extent of Bantayan Island Wilderness Area (BIWA)
column7: which is therefore taken to include the whole island group

The coast of Bantayan and its islands mostly alternates between mangal and palm trees.  Because of the shallow slope on the shelf
column2: the intertidal area can be quite extended
column3: leading to rocky and muddy shallows at low tide.  This means that places with a sandy shore – a beach – are infrequent. Good beaches can be found in the southeast around Santa Fe
column4: and in the northwest at Patao and Madridejos.  Even these though are not cleaned
column5: and depending on the currents there can be considerable amounts of flotsam and jetsam on the beach and in the sea.

column1: Of the approximately 500 varieties of coral known worldwide
column2: about 400 are found in the Philippines.  However their future is seriously threatened – mainly due to destructive fishing techniques
column3: such as blast fishing and cyanide fishing
column4: which indiscriminately destroy much of the ecosystem
column5: including the coral reefs.  In addition
column6: global warming and ocean acidification also contribute significantly to worldwide loss.  Globally coral sees 50%–70% threatened or lost; southeast Asian coral reefs are in even worse condition
column7: and it is estimated in the Philippines the figure under threat is greater than 90%
column8: with less than 1% in good condition.  Until now proper compliance of international laws has been poor
column9: although it is starting to be taken seriously.  Meanwhile
column10: other efforts are under way in Bantayan to accelerate the regrowth

column1: There are many starfish to be seen in the intertidal area. Their detrivorous diet helps keep the water clean.  Further out though
column2: the crown-of-thorns starfish is a considerable threat to the coral reef
column3: because of its voracious hunger for the coral.

column2: woody
column3: seed-bearing plants that are found in tropical and subtropical areas where they are subject to periodic tidal inundation. The Philippines has over 40 species of mangroves and is one of the most biodiverse regions in the world as there are only about 70 species of mangroves worldwide. The mangrove ecosystem is a very diverse one and is home to many birds
column4: fish

column1: Mangroves provide an important nursery for fish
column2: shellfish and other organisms. It is estimated that each hectare of mangrove can provide food for 1
column3: 000 kg of marine organisms (890 lb/acre).  With this abundance of food for fish present in the mangroves
column4: each hectare of mangal yields 283.5 metric tons of fish per year (112.9 long ton/acre). Mangroves also provide other important functions such as preventing soil erosion and protecting shoreline from typhoons and strong waves. Mangroves provide many other products and services such as medicines
column6: housing materials and are an area for research and tourism.

column1: However even with all of these known benefits the state of mangroves within the Philippines is very dim. In the early 1900s there were approximately 5
column3: 900 sq mi) of mangroves but today there are only about 1
column4: 200 km2 (460 sq mi). Many of the mangrove areas were destroyed to make way for fishponds and reclamation areas. They were used indiscriminately for housing – both building materials and reclamation – and were disturbed by siltation and pollution.

column1: Now that the true benefit of these ecosystems is known there is protection and rehabilitation of these important ecosystems. It is now illegal to cut down mangroves for any purpose and local governments and community organizations have taken active roles in planting and managing mangrove plantations. There is hope that in the future mangroves will return to the healthy status that they once held.

column4: and still others say they came from Leyte and Bohol.

column1: There is little documentary evidence of life and culture before the arrival of the Spanish conquistadores.  What we know of them is gathered from handed-down accounts and folklore.
The early people were said to be timid. They did not travel and knew little of places away from their homes. They wore little clothing because the climate did not need it. The abundance of fish

column1: Island of Bantayan. About two leagues north of the island of Çubu lies the island of Bantayan. It is about eight leagues in circumference and two leagues wide
column2: and has a population of about one thousand Indians; this and the above-mentioned island of Vohol are under the charge of one encomendero. Its inhabitants are well-disposed. They have large fisheries
column3: for there are many shoals near the island. There is also a pearl-fishery
column4: although a very small one. The land produces millet and borona
column6: for all the island has poor soil notwithstanding that it is level. Some of the natives of this island cultivate land on the island of Çubu
column9: is two leagues away. The island abounds in excellent palm-trees — a growth common to all the Pintados islands
column10: for all of them abound in palms.

column1: Don José Basco y Vargas was Governor-General of the Philippines from July 1778 until September 1787. During his period in office
column2: he pioneered many projects for the encouragement of agriculture and industries. However many small industries in the islands were completely abandoned because the people were forced to work on building roads
column3: public buildings and churches. Those enforcing were called politas.The abundance of fish
column4: favourable climate and virgin soil then greatly determined the occupation of the people. These geographical factors became strong stimuli for the people to be fishermen
column6: the small clearings were expanded to fields.

column1: When the Spaniards came to Bantayan
column2: the people already had some form of religious convictions and worship
column3: such as animism
column4: shamanism
column5: evocation and magic. They easily conceived the idea of evil spirits
column7: witches and ghosts. In order to please these imaginary creatures people often resorted to charms
column9: sacrifices and self-harm.  It was a common belief among the illiterate people of the past that cholera and other fatal diseases were caused by poison which an evil spirit had put into the wells and that the people could be saved from the dreaded disease only by chanting prayer and holding processions.The cooperation between the church and the state did not last very long. Quarrels between the church and the state ensued. There was struggle for political power
column10: from the Governor-General down to the alcalde mayors on one hand and from the archbishop to the friars on the other. Because of this
column11: projects for improvements were all paralysed.

column2: following the defeat of Spain in the Spanish–American War
column3: a new government was born to the Philippines. With instructions from President McKinley
column4: General Otis
column5: who commanded the US Army in the Philippines
column6: declared that the American sovereignty must be recognized without condition. This was the beginning of the American period.

column1: This island-group did not taken any active part in the revolution against Spain or America. However
column2: after the Filipino–American War
column3: a reactionary group was organized
column4: headed by Patorete of Santa Fe
column5: then still a barrio of Bantayan. Their announced purpose was to resist the invaders
column6: but the armed goons carried a campaign of terror burning the northern part of Santa Fe
column7: plundering and forcing Capitan Miroy and Aguido Batabalonos to join them. This resulted in great fear and tension among the inhabitants.

column2: after the overthrow and immediately preceding the arrival of the Americans
column3: in general
column4: was very far from satisfactory. Sanitation was entirely a stranger; barrio life was dreadful. There were few signs of improvement among the people since their primitive ancestors.

column1: The subdivision of the province of Cebu was developed utilizing the method introduced by Spain. A new provincial law had been enacted in 1895 and necessary appointments were then made. At that time
column2: Bantayan was already organized as pueblo. Santa Fe was organized as such in 1911 and Madridejos in 1917. These pueblos were given a new corporate form under the Municipal Council chosen by a limited native electorate. For the local head of the administration
column3: the title Presidente took the place of the former Gobernadorcillo or CapitanCommitted to the task of administering the newly organized municipal governments were the first presidentes of the three towns comprising the island-group namely: Gregorio Escario for Bantayan
column4: Vicente Bacolod for Madridejos and Casimiro Batiancila for Santa Fe. Political parties were formally organized since the early days of the American regime. Partido Liberal came towards the end of 1900. Pascual Poblete founded the Partido Independista in 1902.

column1: During the administration of Governor-General Luke E. Wright (1904–1906)
column2: the public road policy was inaugurated. Little by little the stage trails were changed to roads of more durable construction. Late in 1913 the construction of Santa Fe—Bantayan road began and in 1918 the Bantayan—Madridejos road followed; both were completed in 1924.
fishing and farming were important industries of the people

column1: Gregorio Zaide described the Philippine national characteristic as "pliant
column2: like bamboo
column3: bending in the wind without breaking". This might explain the war-time actions of the then mayor Isidro Escario
column4: who had himself rowed out to meet a fleet of Japanese warships where he treated with them: Bantayan was not invaded and the war basically passed it by.

column1: Bantayan islands are considered Cebu's fishing ground from where boatloads of fish – guinamos (salted fish) and buwad (dried fish) – are transported daily to Cebu and Negros for consumption and further distribution to as far as Mindanao and Manila. Equally important is the thriving poultry industry with hundreds of thousands of chicken eggs produced daily.

column2: poultry raising was mainly a backyard affair. Today it has grown into a large scale and highly specialized industry. Big poultry farms are located near the national and feeder roads. In excess of one million chickens are kept in yards and specially constructed barns with more than half a million eggs gathered every day. These eggs are exported to Cebu
column3: Manila
column4: and Mindanao and other towns and cities in the Visayas. This industry
column7: has helped Bantayan solve its unemployment problem.

column1: The island can be reached via ferry services from Hagnaya (San Remigio) to Santa Fe
column2: and from Estancia
column3: Iloilo and Sagay to Bantayan municipal port. Bantayan Airport handles infrequent flights from chartered planes usually arriving from Mactan‑Cebu International Airport.

column1: Goods are shipped through Bantayan municipal port.  There is also a small dock in Baigad capable of handling small pumpboats.  However it is in a very poor state of repair
column2: and hasn't handled any vessel since 2007.
